abstract.p: John Pawson: Works, a new book, describes some of projects of architect John Pawson; photo (S)

block.p: Far from an absence of detail, minimalism seems to hinge on an excess of it. How else to explain John Pawson's determination to bore a hole into the bedrock under his London town house, left, to produce geo-thermal heat? ''John Pawson: Works'' (Phaidon, $59.95) is not your ordinary monograph, thanks to lively prose by Deyan Sudjik, the editor of Domus, the Italian design magazine. Chapters on the Calvin Klein showroom and Martha Stewart's stalled makeover of the Bunshaft house in East Hampton, N.Y., frankly reveal an architect striving to cope with perfectionists even more insistent than he. One quibble: arty gray type on white pages shows a lack of respect for the all-too-cruel realities of human sight.
